subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{liushu|p}} – originally two pieces of jade crossed over each other as used in ancient shamanistic practices.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
; “shaman; witch”
: This word initially referred to spirit medium/shaman of either sex, but eventually female when contrasted with {{och-l|覡|male shaman}}. Various hypotheses exist regarding its etymology ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}):
:# Cognate with {{cog|bo|འབའ་པོ||magician, sorcerer}}, {{m|bo|འབའ་མོ||sorceress}}.
:# Cognate with {{och-l|誣|to deceive}}.
:# Cognate with {{och-l|舞|to dance}}.
:# Cognate with {{och-l|母|female}}.
:# {{w|Victor Mair}} (1990) and {{w|Jao Tsung-I}} (1990) proposed that this is a loanword from {{cog|peo|𐎶𐎦𐎢𐏁|tr=maguš}} (more at [[:w:Magi#Possible_loan_into_Chinese|Wikipedia: Magus]]). ({{zh-ref|Mair, 1990}}; {{zh-ref|Mair, 2012}}).

: {{cog|th|หมอ||doctor}} < {{cog|tai-pro|*ʰmo:ᴬ||shaman}} is generally assumed to be a Sino-Tibetan loan ({{zh-ref|Pittayaporn, 2014}}). More at {{w|Wu (shaman)}}, {{w|Magi#In Chinese sources}}, {{m|en|magus}}.

; “Malay”
: {{clipping|zh}} of {{zh-l|巫來由}}, a transcription of {{bor|zh|ms|Melayu}}.
